p: Adolescents rarely hold the power to implement the change and transformation necessary to protect all people from the negative effects of the climate crisis. As illustrated by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Sixth Assessment Report, there is a need for “equitable sharing of benefits and burdens of mitigation” and an enhancement of the resilience of those who are most vulnerable, through a climate justice lens.1 While it is adolescents’ right to have their views taken seriously in all matters that affect them, the responsibility falls squarely on those who hold power—governments, policy makers, and the health community—to lead in responding to the climate crisis.
